shredder 0.1.0

Working With brms

Source: vignettes/brms.Rmd
brms.Rmd
library(shredder)
library(brms)

Generate Data

group <- rep(c("treat", "placebo"), 
             each = 30)

symptom_post <- c(
  rnorm(30, mean = 1, sd = 2), 
  rnorm(30, mean = 0, sd = 1)
)

dat1 <- data.frame(group, symptom_post)

Run Model

fit <- brm(bf(symptom_post ~ group, sigma ~ group), 
           data = dat1, 
           family = gaussian())
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 2000; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 4000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.19625   0.20812 -0.60404  0.20344       3944 0.99998
sigma_Intercept   0.11476   0.13064 -0.12543  0.38149       3136 0.99982
grouptreat        1.45582   0.37031  0.75162  2.18264       3291 0.99934
sigma_grouptreat  0.37435   0.18853  0.01256  0.73583       3707 0.99992

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Select first 100 Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_slice <- fit%>%stan_slice(1:100)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1100; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 400

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.19684   0.21749 -0.62377  0.19696        374 1.00407
sigma_Intercept   0.12740   0.12423 -0.11454  0.38071        356 0.99759
grouptreat        1.45712   0.37856  0.71867  2.13726        213 0.99599
sigma_grouptreat  0.36168   0.17919  0.01457  0.67850        311 1.00087

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_slice%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Sample 25% of Posterior Samples from each Chain

fit_sample <- fit%>%
  stan_sample_frac(0.25)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1250; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 1000

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.19768   0.21551 -0.62677  0.23708       1038 0.99799
sigma_Intercept   0.11815   0.13085 -0.12824  0.38389        931 1.00313
grouptreat        1.44386   0.37259  0.71813  2.14863       1036 0.99918
sigma_grouptreat  0.36793   0.18232  0.01096  0.71443        946 1.00190

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_sample%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional

fit_filter <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 4 chains, each with iter = 1067; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 268

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.41330   0.18610 -0.76146 -0.07538        220 1.02837
sigma_Intercept   0.13354   0.13348 -0.10926  0.39088        239 0.99356
grouptreat        2.16782   0.14357  2.00598  2.50428        155 1.02860
sigma_grouptreat  0.40652   0.19385 -0.00398  0.75817        261 0.99350

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)

Filter Posterior Samples by Conditional Subset Chain

fit_filter_chain <- fit%>%
  stan_filter(b_grouptreat>=2)%>%
  stan_retain(chains = 1)
 Family: gaussian 
  Links: mu = identity; sigma = log 
Formula: symptom_post ~ group 
         sigma ~ group
   Data: dat1 (Number of observations: 60) 
Samples: 1 chains, each with iter = 1067; warmup = 1000; thin = 1;
         total post-warmup samples = 67

Population-Level Effects: 
                 Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Eff.Sample    Rhat
Intercept        -0.44109   0.18687 -0.76158 -0.05817         55 0.99608
sigma_Intercept   0.12993   0.12645 -0.06913  0.37896         38 1.02468
grouptreat        2.15387   0.12995  2.00898  2.51245         55 0.98593
sigma_grouptreat  0.38141   0.18219  0.06896  0.74487         95 0.99876

Samples were drawn using sampling(NUTS). For each parameter, Eff.Sample 
is a crude measure of effective sample size, and Rhat is the potential 
scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1).
fit_filter_chain%>%
  plot(N = 2, ask = FALSE)
